Selected Answer: C

Selected Answer: C

Selected Answer: B
B. Create a Cloud VPN tunnel between Google Cloud and your data center 
 
To securely process highly sensitive data both on-premises and in the cloud without sending it over the public internet, your organization should create a Cloud VPN tunnel between Google Cloud and your data center. This establishes a secure, encrypted connection between your on-premises network and your Google Cloud Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). The VPN tunnel ensures that data remains protected during transit and allows for secure communication between your on-premises environment and the cloud.

Selected Answer: C
C is the Answer

Selected Answer: B
The answer to your question is B. Create a Cloud VPN tunnel between Google Cloud and your data center.

A Cloud VPN tunnel is a secure, private connection between your on-premises network and your Google Cloud Platform (GCP) network. It uses the internet to connect your networks, but it encrypts all traffic over the connection, ensuring that your data remains private and secure.

Selected Answer: C
Option B (Create a Cloud VPN tunnel) might seem like a plausible choice for connecting on-premises to Google Cloud, but it is essential to note that VPNs usually use the public internet to create encrypted connections, which contradicts the requirement that the data cannot be sent over the public internet. Partner Interconnect, on the other hand, establishes a private connection, making it a more suitable option in this case.

Selected Answer: C
Set up a dedicated private network connection between your on-premises infrastructure and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). This can be achieved using Dedicated Interconnect or Partner Interconnect, which provide direct, private, and secure connections between your on-premises data center and GCP's network.

C - A Partner Interconnect connection allows you to establish a dedicated, private, and secure network connection between your on-premises data center and Google Cloud. This connection operates outside of the public internet, providing a direct link with high bandwidth and low latency.

It's B. 

Creating a Cloud VPN tunnel between Google Cloud and your data center would allow your organization to securely transfer sensitive data between your on-premises data center and the cloud. This would involve setting up a Virtual Private Network (VPN) connection that encrypts the data as it is transferred over the public internet, ensuring that it remains private and secure.

A. Configure Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP) in your Google Cloud VPC network: IAP is used to authenticate users before they access the application, it does not encrypt the data transferred over the internet.

C. Order a Partner Interconnect connection with your network provider: Partner Interconnect provides a direct, dedicated connection between your on-premises data center and Google Cloud but it does not encrypt the data transferred over the internet.

D. Enable Private Google Access in your Google Cloud VPC network: Private Google Access is used to allow internal clients to access Google services over VPC network, it does not encrypt the data transferred over the internet.

You see highly sensitive Data and think VPN, however it can't travel through public internet, so therefore it has to be either a Partner interconnect or Dedicated, Since Dedicated is not necessary or available here. It has to be C

Got this from Internet -

Cloud VPN securely connects your peer network to your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) network through an IPsec VPN connection. Traffic traveling between the two networks is encrypted by one VPN gateway and then decrypted by the other VPN gateway. This action protects your data as it travels over the internet.

Here we have to choose " not to travel via Internet"

Refer this -

https://www.google.com/search?q=cloud+VPN+and+partner+interconnect&sxsrf=ALiCzsbOxV3kwtjkiHdrzJSMIPb1KyHwBA:1665218962556&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjM1_GFoND6AhUCS2wGHZcQBNYQ_AUoAXoECAIQAw&biw=1440&bih=692&dpr=2#imgrc=ysesvNS18QlCxM

Selected Answer: B

The question does not provides details to select the right answer. Google recommends to start with VPN as it can handle 1.5 to 3 Gigabits and we can open more tunnels for more bandwidth. At the same time partner interconnect have 50 mbps t0 10 Gigabits/sec speed. The question does not mention how much data we need to transfer, so with the given options B and C both can be correct as both options can handle up to 10 Gigabits of speed. as in partner interconnect also the data will go from the service provider router i would go with the VPN as it is easy to configure and google recommends to start with VPN first. What are your views..?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I would go with B, although both B and C are correct but C is just an overkill. 
This is what Google says about Cloud VPN-
Cloud VPN securely connects your peer network to your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) network through an IPsec VPN connection. Traffic traveling between the two networks is encrypted by one VPN gateway and then decrypted by the other VPN gateway. This action protects your data as it travels over the internet. You can also connect two instances of Cloud VPN to each other.

Reading the question carefully, you can see that it covers all the aspects. 
Partner interconnect is recommended only if you need high throughout.
Why not D ?

There are two ways of connecting on-premises and google cloud. One is Cloud VPN(lower throughput and mainly used for non-prioritized jobs), other is Cloud Interconnect(Dedicated or partnered and mainly used for enterprise-grade connection). In official documentation it was mentioned that google always recommend Interconnect over Cloud VPN. I this this sums up the answer to C.

https://cloud.google.com/network-connectivity/docs/how-to/choose-product

The organization's IT team is responsible for defining data access policies in Google Cloud. This includes defining who has access to what data and how they can access it.

Cloud identity is the tool (not 'who'). And end users shouldn't be defining access - security risk.
Easy, Who is responsible for defining data access policies?, the key is the first word they use for question, We use the question word "who" when we ask questions about a person.
